posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked:
For some odd reason, when we draw a path (in PathPlanner) that is exactly 1 meter long on the x axis our robot goes forward for 1.55 meters. Is anyone else experiencing this issue, and if so is there a solution?

GitHub - metekaradeniz35/2025-REEFSCAPE Contribute to metekaradeniz35/2025-REEFSCAPE development by creating an account on GitHub.

Contribute to metekaradeniz35/2025-REEFSCAPE development by creating an account on GitHub.

posts.name: Dylan Powers
posts.cooked:
I haven’t looked at your code yet but it sounds like you might have an issue with your inverse kinematics.

When you run the path, what does path planner show? Does path planner think the robot is going 1m? Or does it think its going farther?

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked: So in the path planner gui it shows that the robot needs to move 1 meter but when we execute the code and measure the distance the robot has gone it shows that the robot moved 1.55 meters

posts.name: Dylan Powers
posts.cooked: The path planner gui shows it moved 1.55m?

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked: No, its when we physically measure it shows 1.55. The digital field shows that it has moved 1m.

posts.name: Dylan Powers
posts.cooked: Definitely sounds like an inverse kinematics problem. Double check your wheel diameter and gear ratio from your drive motors to your wheels. The robot definitely THINKS its only moving 1 meter.

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked: We tried inversing kinematics but it didn’t changed.

posts.name: Dylan Powers
posts.cooked:
Sorry, I’ve een using the wrong words. I should have been saying forward kinematics, which is the process of figuring out where the robot is based on where the wheels have spun. Inverse kinematics is the opposite process.

I belive there is likely an incorrect value somewhere in your FORWARD kinematics. Likely wheel size or motor to wheel gear ratio. I can take a look at your code more closely later.

To help me out, what kind of drivetrain are you using? What is your motor to wheel gear ratio?

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked: Our drivetrain type is swerve and our motor to wheel gear ratio is 6.12

posts.name: Dylan Powers
posts.cooked: Sorry for my late reply. I took a quick look at your code and everything looks good on a first look. Are you sure you have the L3 gear ratio on your MK4is?

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked: Yes it is L3 gear.

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked:
In fact, when we do not negate the speed, the distance is correct, but the direction is wrong. And when we want to change the direction, the distance increases.

But here, if we look at the code we transmitted, when we go forward, the vehicle stops as if there is no pid and the distance is wrong, but when we go back, the pid and distance are correct.

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: Does this mean that you’ve calibrated the PID ? Did you make sure that all the settings are correct in the GUI? What happens if you run the path really slowly? Do you notice anything new?

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked: we did something else and it is working right now thanks for your supports.

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: I’m curious to know what the problem was?

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked: When we are running robot as blue allience on pathplanner and red on driver station it is working. But for other allience problem is lasting so we still having some problems do you have any idea.

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked:
As a general rule, the problem isn’t fixed until you completely understand why it was happening. Workarounds might be convenient, but they won’t actually help you progress.

Did you try my recommendations?

posts.name: Dylan Powers
posts.cooked:
I don’t know for sure but I believe there is a setting in PathPlanner to mirror your paths along the midline of the field if you are on the other alliance. This was used for the past 2 years as the field was mirrored symetry. This year it is rotationally symetrical so you shouldn’t have that enabled. If your path is getting mirrored, its possible its accidentally going exactly where you want.

I would echo the thoughts of @Strflightmight , keep looking at other solutions.

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked: We did your recommendations but they didn’t resulted

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: What about outside of PP? If you log just the estimated odometry pose after moving 1 meter, does it show any difference in the odometry’s pose?

accepted_answer.excerpt: You might want to check the pathplanner settings. In particular, the robotTrackwidth, driveGearing, and *Module* don’t seem to correspond to what you have in Constants. Also check the driveWheelRadius.
